III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; volunteer,
Title contractors on central registry
Rule Code & (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and suitable
Section and able to meet the needs of children and families served by the
Description agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation The Foster Care Worker has threatened to take licensing action
against the foster parent around parenting visitation.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant X was interviewed by telephone on 2/29/24.
Complainant X did not have any additional information outside of
the information gathered throughout this investigation.
On 2/29/2024, I interviewed Foster Parent X about this complaint
by telephone. I reviewed the details of the complaint with Foster
Parent X, which indicated the case worker and licensing worker
had threatened and harassed her and her husband around issues
with their foster children’s biological parent’s visitations. It was
reported this threat happened via a written text on 2/28/2024 but
has also happened a few other times in the last two months.
Additionally, the Guardian Ad Litem (GAL) and the licensing
worker know about this threat. The foster parents have gone up
the chain of command to complain about the case worker’s
behavior.
Foster Parent X reported this involves Foster Care
Worker (FCW) 3, not the licensing worker. She reported her
licensing worker, Certification Worker (CW) 2 and the children’s
GAL know that FCW 3 threatened them. She reported FCW 3 is
the fifth case worker for Child A and Child B whom they have
2

fostered since 2020 and 2021 respectively. She reported the
children’s case had been moving toward termination prior to FCW
3’s assignment to the case. A petition for permanent custody had
occurred, they were all awaiting permanent custody, but birth
parent and sibling visitations were still occurring. She said her and
her husband have been working with the agency around the
scheduling of these visits. She denied ever not cooperating with
the children’s visitations and reported the birth mother and the
different fathers have consistently missed these visitations. She
reported visitations in December 2023 were not occurring. Those
visits were assumed cancelled due to the birth parents not
confirming the visit 24 hours before the scheduled visit was to
occur, as had been the agreement by the worker/the agency.
Foster Parent X reported, recently the birth mother wanted the
visitation to occur on Saturday, which is difficult for Foster Parent
X, but she had been able to handle it for the past two months.
She reported since termination was originally supposed to occur
on 2/27/2024, she told FCW 3 she could not make the 10am-12
noon Saturday visits due to a standing 10am appointment Foster
Parent X has on Saturday. Foster Parent X suggested an
alternative Saturday visitation time of 8am-10am, and FCW 3
checked with the other parties on that alternative time. The
visitation alternative time change was denied by the birth mother
and the relative who cares for Child A’s and Child B’s two other
siblings. Foster Parent X said she then asked whether the
visitation for the birth mother could occur on a weekday, a
Monday- Friday afternoon for 3:30pm-5:30pm. Additionally, she
asked that they do sibling visitations once a month on Saturday
around noon, as opposed to weekly (the times the birth parent
does not show for the parenting time). Foster Parent X reported
her suggestions were not agreed on. She said, it was after she
was not committing to the original Saturday visit time that she
received a text message from FCW 3 threatening to open up a
special investigation on their foster home and removing Child A
and Child B from their care if she does not comply. Foster Parent
X reported there were two other times where she felt FCW 3 was
either displaying harassing behavior toward her or being
unprofessional in FCW 3’s demeanor. These were via a text
message on 12/5/2023 and 1/19/2024. She reported, FCW 3 was
indicating Foster Parent X was violating licensing rules, but it was
the birth parents missing the visits not them. Foster Parent X
admitted those text messages may not have been actual threats,
but she perceived them as unprofessional and disrespectful.
Foster Parent X also admitted FCW 3 has never been verbally
3

disrespectful to her or her husband. Nor has FCW 3 been
physically threatening to either of them.
Foster Parent X reported calling Supervisor 1 about the 2/28/2024
text message from FCW 3. She left Supervisor 1 a message, but
never received a call back. She also contacted CW 2 with
concern about this alleged threat. During the call with CW 2, she
heard FCW 3 coming in yelling “What is her problem with me”;
and saying, “I would leave early from visitations”. Foster Parent X
reported the latter was not true.
Foster Parent X reported she also called GAL 4 and provided him
a copy of the text message from FCW 3. Foster Parent X
admitted she never reached out to the agency’s director, or a
higher-level administrator about her concerns about the text
messages or with FCW 3.
On 3/12/2024 I interviewed Supervisor 1 by telephone.
Supervisor 1 admitted the case is approaching termination; and
parent visitations are still scheduled. She explained a hearing
related to parental rights termination was to occur on 3/14/2024
and was adjourned to 4/2/2024. These delays likely
caused worry for the foster parents. She denied hearing or
observing FCW 3 to be threatening or unprofessional in her
demeanor to Foster Parent X. Nor had she received any prior
contacts from Foster Parent X alleging such by FCW 3. She said
when she missed Foster Parent X’s telephone call on 2/28/2024
she assumed the call was for that reason, as Foster Parent X had
also contacted CW 2 about the text message.
Supervisor 1 reported she is aware that Foster Parent X was
frustrated with parenting times. The parenting visits for the birth
mother were occurring on Saturday in the community. The
agreement was if the birth parent did not attend the visit, that visit
was to turn into a sibling visitation, and everyone had been okay
with that. Then on or about 2/28/2024, after the time had already
been worked out for the parenting visits, Foster Parent X wanted
to move the visiting time. Supervisor 1 said she was not a part of
the scheduling conversation for those, but it was reported Foster
Parent X wanted to move the visit to a weekday and was not
willing to work with the birth mother’s schedule. Supervisor 1
reported up until this incident in February 2024, Foster Parent X
had been participating and cooperating with the visitation. As the
case grew close to termination Foster Parent X had been
complaining and indicated she was ready for it to be over.
4

Supervisor 1 admitted to seeing the alleged threatening text
message. She said the message indicated if Foster Parent X was
not willing to comply with parenting time we may have to open a
special evaluation or look at moving the children. She said, FCW
3 and another certification worker (Certification 6), came to her
and reported Foster Parent X was complaining and had been
difficult with parenting time in the past. Supervisor 1 advised
those workers if what they said was true then it would be
appropriate to inform Foster Parent X in such a manner as FCW 3
did. Supervisor 1 reported Program Manager 5 also told her what
had been reported about Foster Parent X was accurate.
Supervisor 1 admitted there is no plan or desire to replace Child A
and Child B from Foster Parent X’s home. She denied the purpose
of FCW 3’s text statement was to threaten and frighten the foster
parents with removal of the children. She stated it was appropriate
because the agency does not know what will happen around the
children’s parent’s rights being termination.
Aside from CW 2, Supervisor 1 was not aware of Foster Parent X
contacting any other agency staff or administrator to complain
about FCW 3’s behavior. She said Foster Parent X would contact
CW 2 to try to get things changed to the way Foster Parent X
wanted.
On 3/12/2024 I interviewed Certification Worker 2 (CW 2) by
telephone. She reported she had a working relationship with FCW
3 and the foster parents. She admitted an awareness of the text
message this complaint speaks of, but not its full details. She said
the text was just reminding Foster Parent X they have to be
available for the visits and stay the whole time. She later said
FCW 3 read the text message to her after FCW 3 sent it. She
reported the latter occurring after she received a call from Foster
Parent X who was upset about the text message, and reported it
stated if she did not follow the rule then they would open a special
evaluation and remove the children. CW 2 said she “did not recall
the part about removing the children; or it being said, if they don’t
then we’ll remove the children”.
CW 2 said both Foster Parent X and FCW 3 were frustrated
around issues pertaining to the foster children’s visitations. She
said Foster Parent X would call her when things wouldn’t go
Foster Parent X’s way, and CW 2 would mediate and assist with
getting things worked out. Foster Parent X had also called her a
couple of times with frustrations about the foster children’s parents
cancelling visits at the last minute, or not confirming visits.
5

Additionally, Foster Parent X had reported concerns about sibling
visits being conjoined on Saturdays with parenting time and when
the birth parent didn’t show they had to schedule a different time.
CW 2 said FCW 3 had to make a lot of contacts to get visits set up
and FCW 3 was also irritated about how difficult things were
around the visitation issues. Aside from observing those
frustrations by FCW 3, CW 2 denied witnessing or having any
awareness of FCW 3 threatening, harassing or being
unprofessional to/with Foster Parent X, or Foster Parent X’s
husband.
CW 2 acknowledged FCW 3 came to her office during a time
Foster Parent X was talking with her about the alleged text
message. FCW 3 was upset and made a statement to the effect
“What did I do to make her mad.” FCW 3 was just asking a
question, not talking about the foster parent. CW 2 advised FCW 3
to leave her office and CW 2 finished her conservation with Foster
Parent X. She was then able to assist in getting the Saturday
visitation schedule worked out.
I interviewed Foster Care Worker 3 (FCW 3) about this complaint
via telephone on 3/14/2024. FCW 3 reported being assigned to
Child A’s and Child B’s case for the last eight months. She said
when she first received the case, Foster Parent X said the parents
were always cancelling visits and asked if the agency could agree
to a 24-hour confirmation for visits. Meaning that if the birth
parents did not call to confirm the visit within 24 hours of the set
visit, it would be assumed the visit was cancelled. She said,
visitation for the children’s birth mother were less complicated
earlier when the birth mother lived with the relative that has the
other two siblings. After the birth mother moved, FCW 3 and the
agency had to readjust visits. She said at first Foster Parent X was
agreeing to any parenting time, because most of the time the birth
mother was not confirming them, and Foster Parent X believed the
visit would just get cancelled. FCW 3 reported, around November
or December of 2023, everyone agreed to the birth mother’s
parenting time occurring on Saturday from 10am -12 noon. If the
birth parent did not confirm the visit, that visit would then be a
sibling visit. FCW 3 said two such sibling visits occurred that way.
On the third visit, after the parent had not confirmed, the siblings
caregiver called to reported Foster Parent X cancelled the sibling
visitation. FCW 3 contacted Foster Parent X on the relative
caregiver’s behalf and Foster Parent X asked why they needed to
do sibling visits weekly when they are not required weekly. Foster
Parent X reported having another commitment for the reported
6

Saturday visit and she would not be moving forward with the
sibling visit. FCW 3 said she was texting back and forth with
Foster Parent X. She said she received an email from the GAL
alleging she was trying to force weekly sibling visits, when
parenting visits should be weekly, and sibling visit monthly. FCW
3 explained since the children do not see each other often, she
believed if the birth parents do not show up, why not use that
opportunity for the siblings to visit. FCW 3 tried to get Foster
Parent X to understand this. FCW 3 reported, in an effort to work
through issues, another plan was agreed to at an FTM. There
would be two different Friday visits and two Saturday visits, all to
occur pending the children 2/29/2024 court hearing, where they
thought visitation issues would end, as parental rights termination
would occur.
FCW 3 reported the new plan, (as mentioned above) was working.
Then a week before the 2/29/2024 court hearing the agency was
advised by the Attorney General to pull the permanent custody
petition, and visitation scheduling became a problem. FCW 3 said
she explained the permanent custody petition situation to
everyone on or about 2/27/024. She also spoke with Foster Parent
X again about a need to reschedule visitation for the birth mother
and the siblings. She knew Saturdays didn’t work for Foster
Parent X due to Foster Parent X’s personal commitment, and so
the birth mother and relative caregiver agreed to have visits on
Friday. Then Foster Parent X reported no weekday during the day
worked for her. Foster Parent X gave no explanation as to why
not. Foster Parent X said she could do an evening, which did not
work for the birth mother. Foster Parent X proposed an earlier
time (8am-10am) on Saturday, but the relative caregiver and the
birth mother declined that proposed time due their schedules.
FCW 3 said Foster Parent X kept bringing up issues, so FCW 3
made the decision to keep the visits on Saturday at 10am,
because she felt Foster Parent X was being difficult. FCW 3 said
she spoke with her supervisor and a licensing person about Foster
Parent X not being cooperative around the visits. Those staff
advised her it would be appropriate to let Foster Parent X know if
Foster Parent X did not cooperate with the case plan what could
happen. That was how the 2/28/2024 text message she sent to
Foster Parent X came to be. Her text was advising Foster Parent
X that if Foster Parent X did not cooperate the agency would open
up a special evaluation and would remove the children. FCW said
she is a newer worker, and she was relying on the advice of her
supervisor and the licensing staff. She showed the text to them
before she sent it.
7

FCW 3 reported understanding Foster Parent X’s frustration with
visits and in retrospect is able to see how her 2/28/2024 text
message could be seen by Foster Parent X as a threat. She
stated since the agency’s licensing department had advised her
what to say she assumed it was correct. She admitted the text
was meant to get the foster parent to comply, but not to harass or
threaten the foster parent. She denied being disrespectful or
unprofessional with the foster parents. She admitted despite what
had occurred with the recent visitation difficulties, Foster Parent X
had not refused visits or missed visits in the past. She said Foster
Parent X has given her push back but has, for the most part,
complied.
On 3/14/2024 I spoke with GAL 4. GAL 4 reported the foster
parents are upset about the situation around parenting time visits
and scheduling given that parental rights termination is going to
occur. GAL 4 reported the foster parents are frustrated, because
it seems FCW 3 wants to bend over backward to accommodate
the birth parent for a Saturday visit when the foster parent has
another commitment on Saturday and is free all week. GAL 4
reported agreeing with the foster parent’s frustration, but reported
he was not aware of any physical threats by FCW 3. He recalled
seeing a text message from FCW 3 that if the foster parent does
not cooperate the worker will remove the children.
Documentation Review:
Child A’s and Child B’s MISACWIC case record which showed:
• The children are temporary court wards.
• Child A was placed in Foster Parent X’s and her husband’s
foster home on 9/11/2020; and Child B on 12/1/2021.
• FCW 3 was assigned to the children’s case in September
2024.
• A 9/12/2023-12/8/2023 updated service plan, and social
work contacts which showed Foster Parent X was working
with FCW 3 to negotiate on parenting and sibling visitation
times and locations for the children.
• Documentation of numerous cancelled visits or no shows
by the birth fathers and the birth mother.
Text message thread between Foster Parent X and FCW 3:
• Foster Parent X confirmed a visit for the next day, while
also advising FCW 3 that as of the next week and onward
the time for visits will be changing because the current time
no longer works for her, but evenings after 3pm with the
exception of Thursdays do work.
8

• FCW 3 responded by asking why the time that was
decided on no longer worked.
• Foster Parent X responded: “It no longer works with our
weekend and upcoming events”.
• FCW replied “right you said that. But I am asking for more
detail.”
• Foster Parent X then responded: “Upcoming medical
appointment.”
A 2/28/2024 text message from FCW 3 to Foster Parent X at
12:46pm that indicated:
• “The birth mother and relative caregiver are able to make
Saturdays at 10am work, as originally discussed.”
• “We change the visits so frequently and it is hard to keep
changing the times and days for something that needs to
happen weekly,
• “The consist rescheduling is hurting this case more than
anything, I understand everyone has a life, I understand
everyone has “busy” days, but you are the only one that
constantly gives me push back. I understand you have
obligations, but I am respectfully asking that you plan your
obligations around our parenting time or I will look into a
special evaluation or moving the children to a different
home.”
Analysis The interviews and documentation showed there was a great deal
of frustration around visitation both by the foster parents and FCW
3. Those frustrations and a perceived lack of cooperation by the
foster parent, lead to FCW 3 sending a text message to Foster
Parent X intended to get Foster Parent X to comply as a foster
parent.
Technically Assistance.
FCW 3 would benefit from additional education and training on
engaging and working with foster parents/caregivers. As well as
how to develop strategies toward cooperation without resorting to
written threats during challenging times.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
The agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing rules and statutes.
